action.primary: Induces sweating and releases the exterior

indications: Wind-Heat with body aches and anhidrosis
Hastens the full expression of measles or other rashes to hasten the resolution of the disease
Hot superficial edema (primarily in the upper body with urinary difficulty)

contraindications: Contraindicated for those with any condition with profuse sweating, including Wei Qi Deficiency or Blood Deficiency or Qi Deficiency.
Contraindicated for those with night sweats, and/or thirst and dry mouth from Yin Deficiency.
Use with caution for those with edema due to Yang Deficiency.

useCases: Wind-Heat with fever and lack of sweat.
Measles and Wind rash without full expression of the rash.
Measles and Wind rash without full expression of the rash.
Wind-Edema patterns with swollen face, urinary difficulty and anhidrosis.

notes: This is one of the few cold herbs that is a strong diaphoretic.
It is sometimes used by itself.
It vents pores to bring out sweat.
Some sources say that this herb dispels Wind-Damp, clears Heat and removes toxins.
Its ability to induce sweating is superior to that of Hb. Ephedrae #{MaHuang} Ma Huang and its ability to drain water downward is better than that of Medulla Tetrapanacis #{TongCao} Tong Cao.
There must be severe Excess and great Heat before it can be used.
This herb is appropriate for itching due to Damp-Heat and absence of sweat as opposed to Wind-Cold with absence of sweat.

Both Fu Ping and Hb. Ephedrae Ma Huang open the pores and unblock fluid passageways to induce sweat and promote urination and can be used to treat fever with absence of sweat, urinary difficulty and edema. Fu Ping is acrid and cold and is best used for Wind-Heat in the exterior with absence of sweating. It also promotes urination where there is edema or Damp-Heat and expels Wind to clear rashes and stop itching. It does not relieve cough or wheezing. Ma Huang is warm, acrid and warm and is best for Wind-Cold exterior patterns with absence of sweat. It also controls wheezing and stops cough.
